Nirmal Gyawali (applicant) and The Minister of Citizenship and  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED> )
Counsel:
Michel Montbriand, for the applicant;
Thi My Dung Tran, for the respondent.
Solicitors of Record:
Michel Montbriand, Montreal, Quebec, for the applicant;
Morris Rosenberg, Deputy Attorney General of Canada, Montreal, Quebec, for the respondent.
Summary:
This case is unedited, therefore contains no summary.

[1]
Tremblay-Lamer, J.
: This is an application for judicial review of a decision of the Refugee Protection Division of the Immigration and Refugee Board (the "Board") dated January 22, 2003, wherein the Board determined that the applicant was not a Convention refugee according to Section 96 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, S.C. 2001, c. 27 (the "Act"), nor a "person in need of protection" according to paragraphs 97(1)(a) and (b) of the Act.

[2]
The applicant is a 33-year-old citizen of Nepal who claims refugee protection as a Convention refugee for reasons of imputed political opinions as well as for reasons of risk to life and a serious risk of cruel and unusual treatment or punishment and/or risk of torture.

[3]
The applicant was born in the Lalitpur region of Nepal. During the 1990s he worked for the NGO CARE, did administrative work in a hotel and was co-owner of a hardware store.

[4]
He alleged the following facts:

[5]
On September 21, 1999, the applicant was visiting a village when he met a group of Maoist rebels collecting donations. The applicant refused to make a donation and the rebels threatened him. The next day, the Maoist rebels called the applicant's hardware store demanding 50,000 rupees. They also threatened the applicant and his associate after they refused to pay.

[6]
On November 13, 1999, the Maoist rebels came to the applicant's store demanding the money. They threatened the applicant again. On February 27, 2000, the Maoists returned to the applicant's store with weapons and demanded the money. They started hitting and kicking the applicant and his associate when they refused to pay and took the money that was in their cash register. The applicant and his associate were treated in a clinic and decided to sell their business.

[7]
The applicant started thinking of ways to leave the country, and thought of studying abroad. He applied to colleges in Canada. In June of 2000, the applicant moved from his village to Lalitpur which was a six-hour drive away. The Maoist rebels called him there too and threatened his life.

[8]
On September 3, 2000, the applicant left for Canada to begin his studies. After his departure, the Maoist rebels went to his home and threatened his family.

[9]
The applicant had been planning to return to Nepal after completing his course, but in the last week of January 2002, Maoist rebels burned down his family's house and farm. They also looted the house and destroyed the farm equipment. His family was no longer in a position to send him any money.

[10]
The applicant moved from Vancouver to Montreal and made his refugee claim on February 26, 2002.

[11]
The Board's decision to refuse the applicant's claim was based on its finding that the applicant had not provided credible nor trustworthy evidence. The Board declared it had serious doubts as to the applicant's motives in coming to Canada. It especially questioned why he made no refugee claim upon his arrival to Canada if he had left his country out of fear for his life. The Board also states that the 17-month delay between the applicant's arrival in Canada and his claim for refugee status affected his overall credibility.

[12]
The Board placed great importance on its finding that the inability of the applicant's family to provide him with money was the "triggering event" that led him to make his claim. In addition, it cites the fact that the applicant did not go to the Nepalese police with his problems concerning the Maoist rebels and the fact that he did not attempt to relocate to a larger metropolitan area as being other factors contributing to its finding as to the applicant's lack of credibility.

[13]
Consequently, the Board concluded that the applicant's behaviour is not commensurate with the true subjective fear of persecution required in order to grant a refugee claim.

[14]
The Board also found it implausible that the applicant had not had more problems with the Maoists and questioned the fact that he was not more seriously harmed by them, as opposed to receiving only threats in 1999 and 2000. This finding further eroded the applicant's credibility in the Board's eyes.

[15]
The applicant first submits that he had no obligation to file his refugee claim at any earlier time. He states that from the time he arrived in Canada until the time he filed his claim, he had enjoyed a valid temporary status and was not in a position where he might be forced to go back to Nepal. I agree.

[16]
Although case law generally indicates that failure to apply for refugee status immediately upon arrival or within a reasonable delay can be an important factor to consider in determining a claimant's credibility ( <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  (F.C.A.), there exist situations in which negative inferences may not be drawn and failure to apply for refugee status immediately upon arrival in a Convention country cannot be the sole basis for questioning a claimant's credibility.

[17]
 <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  (F.C.A.), the applicant had worked on a ship for the duration of the five-year delay between his departure from home and his claim for refugee status. The Court found that it was evident he had no fear of having to return to his homeland while he had his sailor's papers and a ship to sail on, that fear was realized only when he was given leave from the ship and was faced with returning to the Seychelles Islands.

[18]
In the case at bar, the applicant had a student visa and had also made an application for permanent residency. It is clear that it was not until he lost his financial support from his family in Nepal that he feared having to return there because he could no longer pay for his studies. Clearly there is a direct parallel with the sailor on the ship who is finally given leave and has nowhere to go but home. Both had left home for fear of persecution and had found a safe place to stay and work, so much so that they did not feel the need to apply for refugee status as they were safe for the time being. Suddenly, both found themselves in peril of returning home through circumstances over which they had no power or influence and immediately filed a claim.

[19]
It is thus not reasonable for the Board to draw any negative inference against the applicant.

[20]
The applicant further submits that the Board erred by ignoring evidence which demonstrates that he could not obtain State protection. Again, I agree with the applicant.

[21]
The Board states that the applicant had presented no evidence demonstrating he had asked for protection from the police authorities in Nepal, nor had he attempted to relocate to a metropolitan area such as Kathmandu in order to flee the rebels. Moreover, the Board claims there is no evidence the authorities would not have protected him had he gone to them for help.

[22]
However, the applicant's evidence clearly demonstrates that the rebels had threatened to kill him if he ever attempted to go to the police, which was the reason why he could not go to the police and chose to leave the country.

[23]
Further, there was overwhelming documentary evidence showing that the threats were extremely serious and that the Board's own evidence showed that police officers were killed in great numbers by the rebels.

[24]
In such a situation as stated by La Forest J. in  <FRAGMENT_SUPPRESSED>  at p. 724: "[...] it would seem to defeat the purpose of international protection if a claimant would be required to risk his or her life seeking ineffective protection of a state, merely to demonstrate that ineffectiveness."

[25]
The applicant further argues that the Board misconstrued the evidence relating to his internal flight alternative (IFA) suggesting that he could have gone to Kathmandu. The evidence shows that the applicant spent three months in Lalitpur, a city that is across the river from Kathmandu, before leaving for Canada. The rebels found him there and threatened him again. Thus, the Board misconstrued the evidence on this point.

[26]
Finally, the Board concluded that it was implausible that the rebels had not been more violent with the applicant. Again, the documentary evidence indicates that the Maoists also intimidate, threaten, harass and extort money from the civilian population in Nepal. Thus, there was nothing implausible in the applicant's story.

[27]
In summary, the Board did commit many reviewable errors which warrant the intervention of the Court.

[28]
For these reasons, this application for judicial review is allowed, the decision of the Board is set aside and the matter is remitted back for rehearing and redetermination before a newly constituted panel.
ORDER

[29]
THIS COURT ORDERS
that the application for judicial review is allowed, the decision of the Board is set aside and the matter is remitted back for rehearing and redetermination before a newly constituted panel.
[End of document]

statutes: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, S.C. 2001, c. 27 (the "Act")
Section 96 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
legal_issues: The extent to which a delay in seeking refugee status impacts the credibility assessment of a claimant.
Whether a claimant’s failure to seek state protection is detrimental to their claim when credible threats exist against doing so.
The standard of evidence required to establish a well-founded fear of persecution.
The permissibility of drawing negative inferences from a claimant’s actions or inactions based on their subjective circumstances and available options.
The proper assessment of an internal flight alternative (IFA) considering the claimant’s demonstrated experience and the risks present in potential relocation destinations.
The evaluation of credibility when assessing claims of persecution based on imputed political opinions and threats of violence.
factual_background: An individual, a 33-year-old citizen of Nepal, applied for refugee status in Canada.
Prior to leaving Nepal, the individual worked in various roles including for an NGO, a hotel, and as a co-owner of a hardware store.
In September 1999, the individual encountered Maoist rebels who demanded a donation and subsequently threatened him when he refused.
The Maoist rebels repeatedly demanded money from the individual's hardware store in November 1999 and February 2000, culminating in a physical assault and theft.
Following the incidents at his store, the individual relocated from his village to Lalitpur.
The Maoist rebels located and threatened the individual in Lalitpur.
In September 2000, the individual travelled to Canada to study.
After the individual's departure, the Maoist rebels threatened his family in Nepal.
In January 2002, the individual's family home and farm were burned and looted by Maoist rebels, resulting in a loss of financial support.
The individual made a refugee claim in Canada in February 2002.
The Refugee Protection Division of the Immigration and Refugee Board denied the individual's claim in January 2003.

Applicants: No obligation existed to file a refugee claim immediately upon arrival in Canada, as the applicant had valid temporary status.
The delay in filing a claim was directly linked to the loss of financial support from family, creating a fear of being unable to continue studies and being forced to return to Nepal.
The Board erred in finding a lack of credibility based on the applicant not seeking state protection, as the applicant feared retribution from the Maoist rebels if he contacted the police.
Documentary evidence demonstrated the seriousness of the threats and the danger to police officers in Nepal, supporting the applicant's decision not to seek state protection.
The Board misconstrued evidence regarding the internal flight alternative (IFA), as the applicant was located near Kathmandu and still threatened by the rebels.
It was not implausible that the rebels’ violence towards the applicant was limited to threats and extortion, as intimidation and harassment were common tactics.
The Board’s finding that the loss of financial support was the “triggering event” for the claim was unreasonable.
Respondents: The applicant’s claim lacked credibility and trustworthiness.
The applicant’s motives for coming to Canada were questionable.
The 17-month delay between arrival in Canada and the refugee claim negatively impacted the applicant’s credibility.
The applicant should have sought protection from the Nepalese police.
The applicant should have relocated to a larger metropolitan area like Kathmandu to escape the rebels.
The applicant’s account of the level of harm suffered from the Maoists was implausible.

court_analysis: The court found the Board erred in drawing negative inferences from the applicant's delay in filing his refugee claim. It distinguished prior case law, reasoning that the applicant, like the sailor in a cited case, had a period of safety and valid status (student visa) that negated an immediate need to claim refugee status; the claim arose only when his financial support was removed, creating a risk of return to Nepal.

The court determined the Board improperly faulted the applicant for not seeking state protection from the Nepalese police. It emphasized the applicant’s testimony that seeking police assistance would have risked his life due to direct threats from the Maoist rebels, and noted documentary evidence supporting the severity of those threats and the danger faced by police themselves. The court cited La Forest J.'s reasoning that requiring a claimant to risk their life seeking ineffective state protection defeats the purpose of international protection.

The court found the Board misconstrued the evidence regarding an internal flight alternative (IFA) to Kathmandu. The Board suggested the applicant could have relocated, but the court highlighted evidence showing the rebels located and threatened him in Lalitpur, a city near Kathmandu, demonstrating the IFA was not viable.

The court rejected the Board’s assessment of the applicant’s credibility based on the level of violence experienced. It found the Board’s skepticism regarding the applicant not being more seriously harmed was unreasonable, given evidence demonstrating the Maoists’ common practice of intimidation, threats, and extortion.

The court concluded the Board’s overall assessment was flawed due to multiple reviewable errors, specifically regarding credibility and the evaluation of evidence, and therefore warranted intervention. The matter was remitted for rehearing before a new panel.
final_outcome: The application for judicial review is allowed.
The decision of the Board is set aside.
The matter is remitted back for rehearing and redetermination before a newly constituted panel.
